commentBody: Very fun and friictionless for a Saturday

"Are you still dating that algebra teacher?"
"No, she's my x."

("Can I find out y?")
At 40.6% faster than my Sat. average, this was one of the easiest Saturdays for me in ages.
For me, virtually everything was 30A and the pace was all 31D.

Very enjoyable and pretty smooth sailing for me. Curious to see what others thought, it seemed like a lot was in my wheelhouse. I see a few other early responders but that‚Äôs to be expected. Worked the NW then SE then SW which all fell like dominos. Then HESAIDSHESAID and the middle. Finally the NW and almost the last entry for me which should have been a gimme, MCFLY, one of my favorite movies!
So, fast but definitely enjoyable. Loved ARMREST and LORELEI and stayed fun from then on even if it was quick‚Äîno complaints here. And a very eye-catching grid with that beautifully stacked center.
An extremely quick Saturday solve.

Puzzle difficulty can be so subjective and I find some days treacherous that others fly through. Ones like this, when I'm one of those flying through, make me appreciate all those other times when it seems like the editors matched the challenge level just right with the day of the week.

For me, this played too fast - a Saturday best five seconds slower than my Monday average - and I'd love a bit more crunchiness in future editions. Now perhaps we'll get a Sunday that'll send me spinning futile wheels for ages....
Given the ELAND just beneath it, could they have gotten away with cluing RECOIL as ‚Äúspring bok?‚Äù
I sped through this puzzle at an uncharacteristically fast pace! Must have been on the same wavelength as the constructor!

I loved the look of this puzzle‚Äôs grid and enjoyed the solve.  To my surprise I finished well below my usual Saturday time.  ARMEST for ‚Äúsubject of an airplane battle‚Äù and LORELEI for ‚Äúfamous rock singer‚Äù were nifty clues.  And the puzzle had lots of fun answers, such as ROADRASH (anyone who has ridden a bike or watched the Tour De France knows about this), DIVVIEDUP, FLOUNCE, and HUMIDOR.
Fun puzzle. Was cruising along until that bottom left. Still about half my normal Saturday time.

Was so surprised to finish this one rather quickly after big struggles at first. 

BABY STEPS!

SE - SW - NE - NW

Definitely not a typical progression for me. 

I haven‚Äôt checked in for a while and I hope all my friends are doing great! The crazy tough puzzle two or three Saturdays ago was a streak breaker for me so I took the opportunity to change my solving routine up a bit. Back on schedule now. 

Have a great weekend!

I had just attended a public event in Bonn at which French President Charles De Gaulle delivered a speech ‚Äî two weeks after a failed OAS attempt on his life ‚Äî and, weary of pedaling upstream, took my bicycle aboard a boat bound for Koblenz. About halfway there, a middle-aged American couple approached me, and speaking slowly, carefully, and LOUDLY ‚Äî to help me understand their English ‚Äî asked me to point out the Lorelei. I had no idea but scanned the horizon for a likely-looking rock. Having found one, in the best Cherman ekzent I could fake, I pointed it out to them. They rewarded me for my assistance with a chocolate bar ‚Äî they had brought a bagful to tip the locals, apparently thinking that it was still late 1945.
Piece of cake

Solid Friday and now Saturday puzzle after a very weak start to the week. 

This puzzle had nice cluing overall, and the one for ARMREST was great. 

Too many names for my liking. YMMV.

Proper nouns shouldn't cross (PATAGONIA LONNIE)

This could have been harder, but at least it wasn't too easy. 

7.75/10

Hello! This is my first time posting, but I‚Äôm a years-long lover of NYT crosswords! They bring me so much joy. I immediately thought of Marilyn Monroe‚Äôs excellent role as LORELEI Lee in Gentlemen Prefer Blondes and her song ‚ÄúDiamonds are a Girl‚Äôs Best Friend.‚Äù

I am generally on the same wavelength as Mr. McCarty - but this was much too easy for a Saturday - 4 seconds over (my already outlying) PB.  Other than the spans, this was Tuesday- Wednesday level.  Having said that, plenty of time for other pursuits Sat morning!
An enjoyable Saturday for me, so likely too easy for others, but I really enjoyed the ‚ÄúFocus of an airplane battle, maybe‚Äù clue for ARMRESTS.
Enjoyable, but easy Saturday. I improved my Saturday best by over a second and better than my Friday best. Loved the cluing for ARMREST.
easiest and fastest saturday puzzle that i can ever remember. when i got 1 across immediately , I had a nice foothold.

I thought this grid was pretty great! Had a little problem with the northwest but still finished faster than i had anticipated. Loved the clue for 1D. And enjoyed learning that the Super Soaker was invented by a JPL engineer.

I solved this a minute and a half faster than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, and I thought Friday went fast! No complaints, I still enjoyed filling in the grid. ROADRASH made me cringe - just picturing it makes me shudder. I was so grateful the day my husband sold his motorcycle üòÖ  Lily GLADSTONE was remarkable in Killers of the Flower Moon. ARMREST was the kind of wordplay that keeps me coming back day after day!! Thank you, Ryan, for another enjoyable solving experience.

I really hate it when people grouse about how easy a puzzle was when I thought it was my own personal genius that got me though it pretty fast, with no serious stumbles and no look-ups.  Now look what you've done.

I kept turning an image of a dogfight between a Spitfire and a Messerschmidt over and over in my head, trying to picture how something, anything in it would fit 1D. Now if Ryan had said. "Focus in the middle of an airplane fight" . . . . Well, it probably still would have been my last fill.  (Brilliant clue!)

The puzzle was imaginative and fun, Ryan.  We're dealing with a bunch of elite, super-solvers here, and if you had crushed them, they would have complained that the puzzle was too hard.  I say Bravo!, and do come back soon.

Nice Saturday. 
Though I suspect faster for most than yesterdays. 

NE was the only corner with bite for me. Despite the fact that the California city was literally in the clue. I kept thinking it was a rebus? For Eureka. 
And kept thinking muttonhead had something to do with lamb. 

But I did enjoy it. 
Really nice set of late puzzles this week.
Saw the granola and decided to treat it as a learning opportunity.
NE Corner was a where I flounced a while.

So wanted ‚ÄúAssistance for Short Drivers ‚Äú to have something to do with the front tee boxes

Very tight puzzle - well done

I just noticed this‚Äîusually the columnists are pretty careful not to put spoilers in the column headline or the photo, yet this one is entitled Baby Steps. Just politely pointing it out for future reference if Caitlin is reading this.
Why SEND for Delight?  Otherwise really nice puzzle - great clues. Going to dig up back to the future DVD

I was sailing along quite nicely until I hit the iceberg. 

I was thinking this was quite easy, then. I had gotten three of the long down answers with little effort.  Finished up the SE and I realized the NE wasn't done.

Those half dozen squares took me the most of the time.

Most of it was caused by thinking [Muttonhead] was Lamb.  I just couldn't come up with anything better, and that made 10D, 11D and 12D very challenging.

I knew there was a poison word in there, but could not decide which one it was.  When I finally tried LUNK, I didn't have much confidence  (I rarely went to movies in the 80s, so a lead role with MC... was virtually impossible).  But that turned out to unlock that corner.

I was really on the point of giving.

Close one.

So I agree with the "easy" crowd for 95% of the puzzle.

If you, like me struggle and then find that others did not, try to take it in stride (something I'm still working on).  I would hazard a guess that some of the most talented crossword solvers in the world are posting here.
Got the gold star in 12:22 to extend my streak to 365 days!

hands down the weakest saturday hit since i started shooting up here nine months ago.
barely felt a whisper of the best bliss.
still jonesing hard.
wheres that mini?
I guess we don't need no stinkin' badges, but I got today's Letter Boxed 6 word puzzle in 2 words.  Shouldn't I get some little something for my lapel for that?

Enjoyed the cluing for ALGEBRA and LORELEI. Perplexed as to why GAS CANS are red - never gave that much thought until now. 

Go Gunners!

Pretty speedy Saturday for me. Each time I thought I was stuck, an answer would pop into my head. Had DIVidED before DIVVIED, rONNIE before LONNIE, and EDMuND before EDMOND, but those were easily found and fixed, and all other proper nouns were fairly easily deduced from the crosses. 

I do have a question about 38A. Could a baseball person explain how HOMER fits with the clue? To my ear, "Knock one out of the park" is a verb, and HOMER is a noun. Is there a way of reading the clue as a noun?
Easy breezy.  New personal best for a Saturday puzzle.

On my own I was able to deal with the middle and the SW of the puzzle.

The NE and SE corners were impossibly difficult for me without lookups. Both areas simply had too many unknowns, mostly proper names. Also, Netflix never offered DVDS in Poland.

In the NW I actually needed reveals, mostly because the clue for ALGEBRA had me completely stumped. Could somebody please explain what that was about? I don't understand the text linked in the column. Is it possible to explain it to a mathematical ignoramus like me?

I also only sort of get the HOMER thing. Knocking one out of the park related to a home run, right? The clue sounds as if the answer will be a verb... HOMER in turn looks to me like a noun? Or is it? I'm so confused!

Not being familiar with muttonhead and only vaguely being aware of LUNK didn't help, either. Also, I don't think I've ever seen the word FLOUNCE in my life. Did the Ministry of Silly Walks sketch on Monty Python's Flying Circus involve flouncing then? ü§£

The cruelty of having DIVVIED UP rather than DIVidED UP was truly Saturday-worthy. It caught me unawares, and was one of the reasons of my failure in the SE. Misremembering SERAPES as South American pancakes was not ideal, either ü§™. Ditto guessing Halley's name was EDMuND rather than EDMOND...

I was quite proud of coming up with some stuff on my own, like MVP and MRS MEISEL. It wasn't enough for a clean solve today though.

This was probably a good Saturday puzzle but simply too tough for me.
Whoo! Fast and fun.

Thought this would be a new Saturday best. After 7 minutes, I had three squares left. Then I thought my streak would end. Put down SARAPES for 34D, since that sounded like a word I knew and tried to brute force Square 49. No dice. Did not make the vacuum connection, so I took my best guess (C for Convenience) and played around with the vowels in SERAPES until I got my Gold Star and 77 Days. Took me as long to solve those last three squares as the rest of the puzzle. 14 minute solve
I bow to anyone who knew LONNIE without the crosses.

Okay, hands up if you had Marty and AAALoans for a bit too long.   No, just me?  :(

The lower right also gave me some trouble but this was a pretty straightforward puzzle experience.  (I'm not in love with the fascist symbol adjacent design pattern that is apparently this constructor's calling card.  But I understand there's only so much you can do with a grid with forced symmetry.)

Anybody want to share something about RAREBIT, and why it's "Welsh" in quotes?

I'd think I'd missed a rebus if I didn't know There Is A Rule about rebuses on Saturdays.

Probably a silly question but does anyone know who I ought to contact about my crossword streak? I have not missed a single day of solving and had a streak of over 700, but flying back from visiting my family in Australia seems to have messed with it, presumably due to time zones, and now it‚Äôs saying I have a 41 day streak. 

If I look through the archive, it‚Äôs all gold stars, so I know I ought to simply ‚Äúknow my truth‚Äù and not pin so much on the streak that the app is telling me, but I didn‚Äôt pay for aeroplane WiFi and sit doing a crossword in transit with two small children climbing all over me, only to ‚Äúlose my streak‚Äù. :(

Any leads on who I need to talk to would be greatly appreciated! The crossword is the only thing keeping me vaguely sane in the trenches of early parenthood!
Quite an easy Saturday. The Springbok clue was helped by the fact that I‚Äôm driving through Etosha in Namibia right now and they‚Äôre everywhere! üòç

Story of my life: When most are grousing, I‚Äôm frequently celebrating personal bests; when y‚Äôall (mc)fly through a puzzle, it‚Äôs a tougher one for me. Not knowing MRS. MAISEL (or was it MR. SMAISEL?) or Lily GLADSTONE was bad enough. But then there was the NE corner, oof. I have never watched Back to the Future or any of its sequels from start to finish, and the bits that I did see‚Äîunavoidably, mostly at slumber parties‚Äîwere under duress and quickly forgotten. We all come across those movies we can‚Äôt stand for reasons that are hard to explain, right? Just like we may get obsessed with a rerun of a complete unknown we happen to bump into while surfing through channels in a bout of insomnia? Yeah, Back to the Future is the former for me. 

As for Lonnie Johnson? God bless the man, the genius who brought father-daughter bonding to a new level‚Äînot to mention the register of my mother‚Äôs voice. Had Super Soaker never come into our local Fred Meyer and subsequently our lives, we may never have known mom to be capable of hitting the high C with so many decibels. I do owe it to Mr. Johnson to remember his first name in the future. 

Other than that the puzzle was pretty straightforward, but somehow‚Äîvery likeable. Fun entries, if not too esoterically clued. Almost no glue, which always gets high marks. I had fun. 

Thanks, Ryan.

Re. the age-old airplane battle (great clue, by the way): It has always been my personal philosophy that the armrests belong to the person in the middle seat. Those beside the aisle and window already have the advantage of better seats, so why not show some mercy to the ham in that unholy sandwich? As an occasional middle-seater who has been elbowed in both sides more times than I can count, I humbly ask your indulgence on my next flight. And when I‚Äôm in bread position, I promise to keep my arms to myself.
Whooosh! That was quick! Today will be a Pogues day: LORELEI https://youtu.be/boJR79qnNkc?si=kG5PJgfioyRQCUSk

I really enjoyed the last couple of days. Themeless puzzles are my favorite and yesterday‚Äôs was a classic. Today‚Äôs was also a lot of fun and rhe clueing must have been right in my wheelhouse as I got my first PB in quite a while with a time a minute and a half faster than my Wednesday time this week. Thanks for the fun!
I laughed out loud at 1 down, must confess to doing my best to grab the ARMREST when ever I flew.  Fun Saturday puzzle.

Seeing that Ryan McCarty was the constructor initially set off alarm bells for me, but I thought this wound up being a puzzle with kinder, gentler cluing than the typical Saturday. Most chuffed (Hi, Sue Jean) in dredging Henry LUCE of Time/Life from the depths of memory with no crosses. And especially loved the clue for LORELEI. In addition to those Gilmore Girls, the name summons up this from the Tom Tom Club. https://youtu.be/82dgacjmP4k?si=rzjpp-gFw60osKR9
The two Cervantes-related clues made me think the grid was supposed to be a windmill. Not sure if it was an intentional theme.

Unusually enjoyable Saturday. Not all that easy for me, of course. A lot of things that were never going to dawn on me just from the clues, but they all came together with pondering and working the crosses. Pretty impressive feat of construction. 

I'll put my usual puzzle finds in replies. 

...
Delightful but on the easy side

It seems like it was just yesterday (in fact, it was!) when I mentioned how many idioms baseball has given the English language, expressions used by many who don't even follow the game at all. This puzzle has one of those idioms: "knock (or more commonly, hit) one out of the park," solving to HOMER (yes, folks, it can be used as a verb, as in "Smith, who homered his last time at bat, is on deck." Here's a whole list of them: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_English-language_idioms_derived_from_baseball And don't forget this Hall of Fame moment: https://youtu.be/C11MzbEcHlw?t=215
Regarding 1Across, It was my understanding there would be no math. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mKAnk2XVnDE

Polished, oh so polished, this grid!  An uber-low 62 words, chunks o‚Äô white aplenty, not only packed with a cluster of varied and interesting answers, but void of clunkers anywhere.  Simply gorgeous.

Ryan likes this grid design ‚Äì he used it in January.  In that puzzle, tough for me, I went from headstrong, to humble, to hope, to happy ‚Äì one sweet solve.  

Today, therefore, I started humble, and as a result, every answer I filled in felt like a happy surprise.  Being pummeled by happy surprises, hey, that is a sweet solve as well.

And then FLOUNCE, a word that brightens my day every time it crosses my path. Today it triggered the image  of an ostrich doing ballet.  I also loved [Focus of an airplane battle] for ARMREST, not to mention the PuzzPair¬© of DADS TO BE and BABY STEPS.

Ryan, you are one of the kings of Saturday, and I never know what to expect, except gladness for having done them.  Thank you for your humor and mastery, and for a splendid outing today!

Uncharacteristic for me to start a Saturday puzzle in the NW, but ALGEBRA, ARMREST and LORELEI had me grinning. I thought for sure I'd breeze through the rest of it. And for the most part I did, though the SE took a bit of time. I never heard of them referred to as CSTORES, but once I had STORES, it became obvious.

I got through the middle fairly easily, thanks to HE SAID SHE SAID coming right to mind. But then then that darned NE. Stumped, even though CAR LOANS was my immediate entry there. The rest of that corner dogged me to the very end, and I nearly gave up. But then I had a thought: What if 18A, Facedown, wasn't one word, but the two words I always thought it was? That's when I got PRONE, and that made me think of MVP, which gave me MC, remembered MCFLY, then was able to get FLOUNCE, YREKA, and finally, LONNIE. Whew! The easy puzzle turned into quite a workout, but persistence sure paid off. I really enjoyed this puzzle!
Raise your hand if you've ever referred to a convenience store as a C-STORE.

Nice walk down memory lane as I recalled the red envelopes that DVDS from Netflix used to come in.  Amazing to think that was still an option until 2023.  I came across one of those old envelopes a decade ago, and it made me smile thinking of days long gone by.
I remember when the company first came into existence and thinking, "Why would anyone wait for a DVD in the mail when Blockbuster is just around the corner?"
Now I had to Google "DVD chain store" to remember the name Blockbuster!
Great puzzle. On the easier side for me, but full of twisty fill. 1D had me trying to fit in Dogfight for ages.

Much too easy for a Saturday puzzle---until I hit the NE corner, which took almost as much time as the rest of the grid combined. Don't think I've ever seen YREKA, and it took me much too long to get MCCOY out of my head and allow MCFLY to pop in.

Didn't enjoy this one very much, largely due to the geometry of the grid. Felt like I was solving minipuzzles, especially so in the NW and SE corners. The central mass of lengthy entries was remarkably easy to solve, since I knew that almost all the boxes would need to be filled by very common letters to make things work.

Solid enough puzzle, but somehow not very satisfying to solve.

I like a challenge, so this was a little disappointing for me.  But still it was a beautiful puzzle with lots of fresh solves and a few well-written clues.

I went along very smoothly until I hit the NE at the end.  McFLY, VALOR, FLOUNCE, LONNIE, and of course YREKA, all required several crosses for help.  Thank goodness A'ja Wilson's award was simply MVP.  I was afraid it was going to be a named award like Conn Smythe.  Maybe one day it will be the "A'ja Trophy".

I could never really call a NYT Saturday crossword ‚Äúeasy‚Äù, but this one was relatively quick and fun. It felt more playful to me than most late-week puzzles. Ryan McCarty is amazing.

Regarding LORELEI, I‚Äôm not sure I should admit this but I thought of Lorelei Lee in Gentleman Prefer Blondes (played by Marilyn Monroe in the classic 1953 movie version). She famously sang about ‚Äúrocks‚Äù too, Diamonds Are a Girl‚Äôs Best Friend got me the right answer, but imagine my surprise when I was reminded here of the other classic LORELEI. Then I thought: Oh, her!

So fun! A lot of ‚Äúoh that was great‚Äù moments, like:
CARLOANS as [assistance for short drivers] and 
ICECUBES as [water cooler?]

I also loved seeing LONNIE Johnson here, and plugging in HESAIDSHESAID felt good! So glad it was correct!

Many commenters have mentioned modern songs and TV shows that include a LORELEI, but I haven't seen anyone quote the original poem by Heinrich Heine.  Here is its tragic conclusion, in German.

Die sch√∂nste Jungfrau sitzet
Dort oben wunderbar,
Ihr goldenes Geschmeide blitzet, Sie k√§mmt ihr goldenes Haar.
Sie k√§mmt es mit goldenem Kamme
Und singt ein Lied dabei;
Das hat eine wundersame,
Gewaltige Melodei.
Den Schiffer im kleinen Schiffe
Ergreift es mit wildem Weh;
Er schaut nicht die Felsenriffe,
Er schat nur hinauf in die H√∂h.
Ich glaube, die Welllen verschlingen
Am Ende Schiffer und Kahn;
Und das hat mit ihrem Singen
Die Lorelei getan.

Well that was a surprise.  First reaction when I viewed the grid with what appeared to be not a lot of black squares was "Uh oh", but as I dug in, things moved smoothly and before I knew it, the grid was half full.  The rest went about the same, with some slight resistance in the NE.  60% below my average.

Hi folks, nice to see you. I solved this puzzle and I liked it a lot it but it was oddly quick‚Äîit took me just slightly more than half the time of yesterday‚Äôs.

I didn‚Äôt know the LORELEI story and just kept thinking of Steven Universe, which sort of worked anyway. 

And I had a real dook with DADSTOBE. I kept deleting the B, saying to myself, ‚Äúdad stobe can‚Äôt be a thing.‚Äù
ARMREST made me smile.
I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen the word divvy in print. If I have, it went right by. DIVVIEDUP caused some confusion.
I think the explanation of "field" in the column was overthought. I just took it to mean an area of study.
This was my fastest Saturday solve ever. I'm not sure how!

Sooooooo....late yesterday the overly-vigilant emus released my (completely harmless) Comment, along with several others that had been held up.  

You'd think they'd want to make it up to us with a humdinger of a Saturday puzzle...and the Wide Open Spaces of the grid, at first, seemed daunting... 
....but instead, Hippity-Hop from the SE corner--could scarcely write fast enough!--up and down, around and around, and Pfft.  Over   Too    Soon!

And who says C STORE?  Nobody.  Folks manage to pronounce 'convenience' without too much of a struggle.  Sheesh.
Now what am I supposed to do?
The Bonus Puzzle isn't even by Fred Piscop.  No offense, Chandi, congrats and all, but we had a tradition ....or so we thought.
Tuesday level üòê. I need to get my day going, so not entirely a bad thing. There's always the archives to get my difficulty fix later on. Puzzle was super fun so all good.
Two Fridays in a row! Now that's a week I can get behind

Steve L.,

I was just now circling back to see if you responded to a reply I made to your comment on 10/1 regarding posting about Connections in this forum and see now the whole thread is gone.  Any idea why it was removed?

NE corner. Started with ROCKY, as an educated guess. Then changed to MARTY (close!), which tied things up for a while, including leading me to AIRBRAKE for the "short" driver, which eventually became CARSEAT, which kinda works, but is a bit alarming.

What a coincidence that we just finished watching  Killers of the Flower Moon last night. It's very lengthy and we had to split it up into two nights.

Every time Lily Gladstone appeared, all I could think of was William Hale's line: "she's easy to like."
Almost every time William Hale appeared, all I could think of was his line: "I'm a 32nd degree Mason!"
When Brendan Frazier made his appearance, all I could think of was "wow, Imhotep really did a number on you."

Definitely one of the better movies on streaming services, as of late.
16 minutes for a Saturday puzzle! I know that's no big deal for many of you folks, but for me, that's astounding. (I attribute this to the puzzle's construction and clues, not to anything about me.)
No difficult. But still too many obscure proper nouns.

A smooth one but also had a bit of a rockY time in the NE.  At [Water cooler?] I thought, "I hope it's not,  oh it is ICECUBE" which prompted the lookup:

ICECUBE: 15 previous instances but the only other Saturday was [Producer of a chilling effect] (not bad).  My favorite however is [Die of cold?] from a variety puzzle 1/13/2002.  

Nice puzzle.  Thanks.
Assertion: the person sitting in the middle seat on an airplane should be granted control of both of their ARMRESTS.

Almost a personal "best" today. After 10 years of daily play, this very rarely happens.

Although "faster" does not generally equal "better" in my book, today was a good day for it.

This was a very smooth Saturday for me, squarely in my wheelhouse I guess. I thoroughly enjoyed it, especially the misdirect clues such as 9D.

The two Quixote clues in close proximity to one another added a delightful literary touch.

Thank you, Ryan McCarty.

Despite the world, there is simple joy in solving a crossword puzzle.
Unblemished, innocent joy!

Thankful for the peace and pleasure of puzzles.
As for the rest, this too, shall pass.
Finally solved this one when I realized 8A was MCFLY not ‚ÄúMcFry.‚Äù The 80s were a strange time for movies, but no, there was no Hamburglar movie I forgot about.
I was very amused to see 12D given that I'm heading to Yreka later this morning! (No, not from Phoenix; I'm currently a lot closer to Yreka than that.)

Strange things are afoot at the Circle K.

C STORES? Whatever. I never ordered DVDS from Netflix, seems tedious. We got ours from the RedBox machine, which was in front of the Royal Farms. And I still have a Blockbuster card in my junk drawer. How did we ever manage without video on demand? Waiting patiently for the Movie of the Week to come on, for example. And you couldn't pause it to go make more popcorn.

Where was I in 1985? That was my first thought! Give the question some context. After a bit, ah yes, Back To The Future.
I had MARTY at first. It became clear that was incorrect as I worked out the puzzle. I doubt I would have remembered MCFLY on my own, but at least I was zeroed in on the right character. 
This is the first Saturday I've finished in quite a few weeks, and this was not accomplished in record time lol, but it was very satisfying to achieve the Gold Star. 
Have a good one everybody, cooler, more comfortable days are upon us, thank goodness, pumpkin spice lattes all around!

TIL there's a magazine called "Time, Life and Sports Illustrated".

Sounds like a children's version of "Life, The Universe and Everything".


(Deep Thoughts!)(42!)
This one really clicked for me for some reason. Set a new PB that was 60% quicker than my normal Saturday average (and even quicker than my Friday PB). What a great way to start the day!
Nice to hear from Lorelei again. Look out sailor!

This Saturday puzzle seems to have been salted with an undue number of virtual gimmes: "Field of unknowns" for ALGEBRA, "Colorful shawl" for SERAPE, "'Welsh' dish with melted cheese" for RAREBIT", "Sucker, for short" for VAC, "Source of some flashbacks" for LSD, "Stopped vacillating" for OPTED. 

And I confess that  found the clue for YREKA to be ridiculous: It is famous among wordgame fans that the Yreka Bakery is a palindrome. But I've never once heard of anyone who suspected the town's name Yreka arose from spelling the word "bakery" backwards.

I had the (somewhat) good fortune of living within an hour's drive or so of the Lorelei in the mid-80s, while stationed in West Germany with the US Air Force. The promontory is located on one of the more beautiful and scenic sections of the Rhein (or Rhine) with views of several castles. And just a couple years ago, we cruised the Rhein and Mosel (Moselle), once again (safely) passing by the Lorelei.

Late answer history search - actually a couple of weeks late. 15 letter answer that dawned on me was: AUTUMNALEQUINOX It's been an answer in 3 puzzles and part of the theme in each of those. First - a Friday from February 21, 1992. Other theme answers in that one: SHORTESTDAY (clued as "Dec. 21 -22) and HARVESTMOON. And then a Friday from March 10, 1978 by Maura B. Jacobson. Two other answers in that one: ECLIPSEOFTHESUN WINTERSOLSTICES And finally - a Sunday from January 26, 1969 by William Lutwiniak with the title "Changing world." Some other answers in that one: WINTERGREEN SOMERSAULTS FALLABACKON SUMMERHOUSE SPRINGASURPRISE SPRINGFIELD and... OUTOFSEASON Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/26/1969&g=22&d=A ...

I'll take care of the easier one first.  HOMER can be a noun or a verb.  "He hit a homer in the second."  and "If he can homer, the game will be tied."

Now the algebra one.  I'll try.  In arithmetic we are given number and expected to do something with them:  such as 5(3)+18.  We can do the arithmetic and come up with 33.

In the field of algebra, we identify a number with don't know with an variable, mostly commonly "x".  That the think we don't know.  However, we are told that if we multiply our unknown, x by 5, and then add 13, we get 33.  

Translating the language to the equation gives us 
5(x)+13 = 33.  

Algebra is the "field" which enables us to find this "unknown" x in this equation.  Field of unknowns.

I doubt you want any more than that.
